awd_titl_txt: A combined mathematical and bioengineering approach to elucidate the contribution of circadian factors in the cellular response to genotoxic stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Circadian rhythms are mechanisms that measure time on a scale of about 24 hours and then adjust the body to environmental signals. Circadian clock genes produce proteins that are necessary for the generation and regulation of circadian rhythms. These proteins also regulate genes involved in either cell division or cell death. Agitation in the balance between cell division and cell death will lead to cellular dysfunction. In this project, the investigator will use an interdisciplinary approach that combines biological, mathematical, and bioengineering tools, to examine the circadian factors that act as mediators in the interconnected network that controls the circadian clock.  This project includes an educational component that will recruit, retain, train, and graduate a more academically prepared student body with a global vision of interdisciplinary research and world opportunities, creating a new sense of leadership. 

This project uses multidisciplinary and complementary methods to establish signature events that modulate the effect of genotoxic stress in both cell division and circadian phase resetting across length scales from molecular to cellular systems. Initially, the study will focus on intracellular events that dynamically adapt themselves to genotoxic or physiological challenges to what cells are exposed to. Then, the study will shift toward understanding how redistribution of clock and checkpoint players influence the clock itself and promotes resetting. To accomplish this goal, the investigator will integrate diverse experimental observations and measurements into mathematical models that simulate concrete and realistic experiments, reconcile measurements and current data, and illuminate how different components cooperate to produce a particular behavior. Lastly, additional experiments will be designed to explore the influence of the microenvironment and systemic factors in the clock response to genotoxic stress and to the circadian behavior of multi-cell arrangements in three-dimensional substrates. As a result, the investigator proposes to: (1) determine how spatial/temporal organization of circadian components modulates the cellular response to genotoxic stress and provokes clock resetting; and (2) study the behavior of circadian oscillatory systems challenged by genotoxic stress in 3D biomimetic environments. The transition to a system that more closely resembles physiological conditions will expose additional critical parameters and provide a more comprehensive map of crosstalk mechanisms, help predict network connections, and generate new testable hypotheses.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of our proposal was to understand, at the single cell level, how the molecular mechanisms that monitor cell cycle progression through the day couples to environmental changes. This allows for mammalian cells to consistently divide at specific times. Importantly, when cells experience environmental stress conditions, e.g., exposure to different forms of radiation, division is halted until damage to the cell’s DNA is repaired. As a result, the clock that controls the time of progression through the different phases of the cell division cycle needs to be reset. We proposed to use a combination of cell/molecular biology and mathematical modeling approaches to elucidate the interplay among molecules that drive progression through the cell cycle in a timely manner. Furthermore, we studied how those molecules reorganize and respond to stress signals and whether uncoupling of the clock and cell division cycles results in uncontrolled cell proliferation, a phenomenon of relevance for cancer initiation and progression.

In general terms, our findings show that PERIOD 2 (PER2), a unique circadian factor responsible for maintaining the time-keeping system known as the circadian clock, influences the cellular response to genotoxic stress and the resetting of the circadian clock in mammalian cells. We identified a critical node of regulation where the circadian pathway, through PER2, intersects with the DNA-damage signaling cascade at a critical juncture with the tumor suppressor p53, a master transcriptional regulator of a plethora of cellular processes. Our results show that PER2 modulates p53’s stability and function as a regulator of gene expression. Furthermore, we determined that p53’s negative regulator, the oncogenic protein MDM2, targets PER2 for degradation, a result that influences the clock system in the cell. The interplay among PER2, p53, and MDM2 influences the cell’s response to stress as it directly modulates the expression of genes involved in cell cycle progression, DNA damage response, and cell death, among other cellular processes. In summary, our results indicate that deregulation of processes that affects PER2 homeostasis impacts cell division and proliferation.

Educational activities were an active component of our proposal. Our program focused on training high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students from southwestern Virginia and Latin America by giving both groups unprecedented professional and cultural experiences to foster understanding and professional development. Overall, our program’s initiative encouraged students to pursue careers in science, experience professional growth, explore particular academic interests, and understand and appreciate different cultures.
